potential improvements provided by these strategies are case
specific and not thoroughly evaluated in
the literature, either individually or as a combination of multiple strategies.
here is an increasing use of advanced materials such as high
and polymer composites for vehicle light weighting
materials reduce the mass of the vehicle and thereby also reduce the fuel or energy required to drive.
weighted components often have higher production emissions than
due to the advanced materials used
emissions, some studies suggest that the reduced fuel consumption over the lifetime of the light

(Hottle et al. 2017; Kim and Wallington 2013; Upadhyayula et al. 2019; Milovanoff et al. 2019;
. However, multiple recent publications have found that in some cases, depending
on, for example, vehicle size and carbon intensity of the light weighting materials employed, the GHG
emissions avoided due to improved fuel efficiency do not offset the highe
. In addition, these advanced materials may be challenging
to recycle in a way that retains their high technical p
Light weighting may also alleviate the particulate matter (PM)
emissions arising from road and brake wear
BEVs are generally heavier than their ICEV counterparts,
which may potentially cause higher str
ess on the road surfaces and tires, with consequently higher PM
ive braking in HEVs, BEVs and
FCVs, however, reduces the mechanical braking required, and therefore may compensate for the higher
brake wear emissions from these heavier vehicle types. In addition, BEVs have no tailpipe emissions,
increased PM emissions from road and tire wear. Therefore, light
strategies may offer a carbon and particulates mitigation effect; however, in some cases, other
